| alt = caption = So-called "Logios Hermes" (Hermes,Orator). Marble, Roman copy
| from the late 1st century BC - early 2nd century AD after a Greek original of
| the 5th century BC. god_of = Messenger of the gods God of commerce,
| thieves, travelers, sports, athletes, and border crossings, fish, guide to the
| Underworld abode = symbol = Caduceus, Talaria, Tortoise, Lyre, Rooster, Snake
| consort = Merope, Aphrodite, Dryope, Peitho parents = Zeus and Maia siblings =
| children = Pan, Hermaphroditus, Tyche, Abderus, Autolycus, and Angelia mount =
| Roman_equivalent = Mercury
}} 'Hermes' (; Greek ) was an Olympian god in Greek religion and mythology, son
of Zeus and the Pleiad Maia. He was second youngest of the Olympian gods.

Hermes was a god of transitions and boundaries. He was quick and cunning, and
moved freely between the worlds of the mortal and divine, as emissary and
messenger of the gods, Iris had a similar role as divine messenger.
intercessor between mortals and the divine, and conductor of souls into the
afterlife. He was protector and patron of travelers, herdsmen, thieves, orators and wit, literature and poets, athletics and sports,
invention and trade. Walter Burkert, Greek Religion 1985 section
III.2.8. In some myths he is a trickster, and outwits other gods for his
own satisfaction or the sake of humankind. His attributes and symbols include
the herma, the rooster and the tortoise, purse or pouch, winged sandals, winged
cap, and his main symbol was the herald's staff, the Greek [[kerykeion]] or
Latin [[caduceus]] which consisted of two snakes wrapped around a winged
staff. The Latin word {{lang|la|cÄdÅ«ceus}} is an adaptation of the Greek {{lang|grc-
Latn|kÄrukeion}}, meaning "herald's wand (or staff)", deriving from {{lang|grc-
Latn|kÄrux}}, meaning "messenger, herald, envoy". Liddell and Scott, Greek-
English Lexicon; Stuart L. Tyson, "The Caduceus", The Scientific Monthly,
'34'.6, (1932:492â98) p. 493

In the Roman adaptation of the Greek pantheon (see [[interpretatio
graeca|interpretatio romana]]), Hermes was identified with the Roman god
Mercury, who, though inherited from the Etruscans, developed many similar
characteristics, such as being the patron of commerce.
